data.title: Only use electron version in fingerprint
data.body:
Previously the CI fingerprint used a SHA-1 of the entire `package.json` contents to determine when to clear the `node_modules` folder.

This would cause lots of clearings of that folder on CI since `master`, `beta`, and `stable` branches all have different `version` values that can change often.

Now only the `electronVersion` value is used in the fingerprint meaning that `node_modules` will only be cleared when the minor version of Electron changes which is why I believe this clearing was originally added before the fingerprint check was incorporated.

/cc @thedaniel @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Everything feels slower on a retina screen
data.body:
Hey,
I recently switched from ST to Atom and I noticed that it feels really slow to even write on a retina screen. I think this issue is partly addressed in #1666 but I feel that starting a new conversation about performance on Retina displays is necessary since it is unbearable right now.

I used a tool called [Retina Display Menu](https://roaringapps.com/app/rdm-retina-display-menu) to quickly switch between Normal & Retina Displays and used Dev Tools to capture this information while I pressed Arrow Down key a few times to scroll a 400 line .js file:
#### Non-Retina

![Non-Retina](http://i.imgur.com/r8GDjcP.png)
#### Retina

![Retina](http://i.imgur.com/Sbtng1Q.png)

It seems quicker to complete on retina screen but the general experience was really bad due to low FPS. Although it only shows information about a few seconds, it might give you an idea about how it lacks responsiveness on a Retina screen, and this holds true even when writing code (Although not as extreme as scrolling). 

Btw, experience on retina screen with `atom --safe` seems much better **compared to retina in normal (non-safe) mode** but I do not think it is related to any package since it is still not as good as **`atom --safe` with non-retina**. 

So, any ideas about where to start to fix this?

data.title: Cannot see Project Tree View
data.body:
This error appears to be related to Nuclide so I am not sure where I should be posting it, but the link from with Atom took me here so there is where I will post it.  Basically after installing and uninstalling Nuclide Atom tends to not perform as well.  This is when I began to not see my tree view of the project even after having restarted Atom multiple times.  This a probably an edge case but now it is documented :)
1. Install Nuclide
2. Add a new project folder
3. Restart Atom

data.title: Cannot rename file from window titlebar on OS X
data.body: It is standard practice in OS X document editors to be able to rename a file by clicking the current filename in the titlebar of the window, at which point one is allowed to "type" in the title-bar to effortlessly rename the file. Try this in Pages/Numbers/Keynote/TextEdit. This should be possible in Atom.

data.title: Extending TextEditor functionality is not trivial
data.body:
Trying to extend the functionality of the TextEditor seems unnecessarily difficult. Doing the following results in an error

```
{TextEditor} = require 'atom'
class MyCustomEditor extends TextEditor
```

ERROR:

```
Uncaught Error: Must pass a config parameter when constructing TextEditors
```

Overriding default functionality becomes difficult and results in [hacky solutions](https://github.com/adrianlee44/atom-coffee-compile/commit/c50d31a9c1e9ac8722e7692eb99e7dd4da66fc03#diff-8cf67b8cb46941d3297a4538472734a4R117) to overcome the issue. These kind of solutions are probably very prone to breakage as atom updates and is therefore not ideal.

Could we please have a straightforward way of extending core components in the Atom api?

data.title: apm test/atom --dev --test displays wrong file names
data.body:
How to reproduce this bug:
1. Open a package or create a new one.
2. Run `apm test`. If you created a new package with package-generator, the specs will fail and display an error like `Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee:5:20)`.
3. Rename `spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee` (I renamed it to `testing-package-view2-spec.coffee`).
4. Run `apm test` again.

The specs fail (as expected), but instead of showing the new file path, it shows the old one.

I assume this is a caching issue, because clearing `~/.atom/compile-cache` fixes the bug for me.

```
$ apm test
...

TestingPackageView
  it has one valid test
    Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee:5:20)


Finished in 0.306 seconds
3 tests, 9 assertions, 1 failure, 0 skipped

Tests failed
$ mv spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee spec/testing-package-view2-spec.coffee 
$ apm test
...

TestingPackageView
  it has one valid test
    Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view-spec.coffee:5:20) <--Wrong path


Finished in 0.185 seconds
3 tests, 9 assertions, 1 failure, 0 skipped

Tests failed
$ rm ~/.atom/compile-cache -R
$ apm test
...

TestingPackageView
  it has one valid test
    Expected 'life' to be 'easy'. (spec/testing-package-view2-spec.coffee:5:20)


Finished in 0.316 seconds
3 tests, 9 assertions, 1 failure, 0 skipped

Tests failed
$ atom -v
1.4.1-2cf2ccb
$ apm -v
apm  1.5.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 3.5.1
git 2.6.4
```

data.title: Properly restore initialPaths so project paths are not loaded as files
data.body: If project folders no longer exist or are not mounted, then Atom would open them as buffers, which are empty because the corresponding file did not exist (and if it did, it would be a directory, which would make little sense). This threads the right state through the startup sequence so that `initialPaths`, which actually are project roots, are restored correctly.

data.title: Swap Command/Control keys (cmd, ctrl)
data.body:
Swap Command/Control keys for all Atom shortcuts. Atom has different keyboard shortcut defaults based on platform. On Mac, it uses `cmd`, and on Windows, `ctrl` for many modifier combos.

The goal is to have the Windows keyboard shortcut defaults on a Mac. This could end up being able to choose which set of keyboard shortcuts to use. Or even alias control to command via a hook as [mentioned here](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/2349#issuecomment-45924381).

For now, a possibility is to write a script to swap them all and put them in the `keymap.cson` or copy of the [platform specific configs](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/keymaps/win32.cson) into `keymap.cson`.

---

I am using [ShareMouse](http://www.keyboard-and-mouse-sharing.com/)_([Synergy](http://synergy-project.org/) is another alternative)_ so I can seamlessly move from a Windows machine to Mac with one set of keyboard/mouse. But this also means that I often hit the wrong key combo the first time, using `Ctrl+C/V` on mac, etc.

For basic shortcuts, such as copy/paste or anything else listed in the top menu, you can use [this trick](http://superuser.com/a/363355/130885) to alias it over. But many of the atom commands are in the internals that can't be mapped this way.

As an aside, if someone knows how to map `ctrl` key events to `cmd` on Mac, this would be a solution. _note:_ swapping the functionality via _System Preferences -> Keyboard -> (Keyboard tab) Modifier Keys..._ only applies to the keyboard hooked up to the mac itself and the physical keyboard in my setup is on the Windows machine. Probably would work to have it the other way around though.

data.title: Atom fails to correctly read any files including its config and packages
data.body:
When I start atom, the editor complains that it can't read config.cson and packages (nothing new modified or installed). Opening any file in atom gives me rubbish characters whatever the encoding. Opening the same file in another editor works fine.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/733386/12673655/57e2c844-c67e-11e5-815a-9a43670cb39d.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/733386/12673659/5aeeeebe-c67e-11e5-9468-d6419326c08e.png)
I have to reboot the computer to get it right. After a few start/stop of atom (I can't figure which event breaks everything) the bug reapears.

Trying to start atom from the command line (cmd.exe), I get
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/733386/12673666/6317bc24-c67e-11e5-85b1-3ec8e4497123.png)

Safe mode does not work either.

I upgraded from 1.4 to 1.4.1, same behavior. I tried to disable my packages, no success.

I'm running on W7. 

Any clues ?
